Name: Xeric sites
Description: normally low or deficient in available moisture

Name: Dry Tops
Description: Ridge tops with thin rock outcrops and considerable exposure to sun and wind.

Name: Dry Slopes
Description: Slopes with thin rock outcrops and considerable exposure to sun and wind. Includes most mountain/steep slopes with a southern or western exposure.

Name: Deep Sands
Description: Sites with a deep, sandy surface subject to rapid loss of moisture following precipitation. Typical examples include sand hills, ridges, and flats in the South, sites along the beach and shores of lakes and streams.

Name: Other Xeric
Description: All dry physiographic sites not described above.

Name: Mesic sites
Description: normally moderate but adequate available moisture

Name: Flatwoods
Description: Flat or fairly level sites outside of floodplains. Excludes deep sands and wet, swampy sites.

Name: Rolling Uplands
Description: Hills and gently rolling, undulating terrain and associated small streams. Excludes deep sands, all hydric sites, and streams with associated floodplains.

Name: Moist Slopes and Coves
Description: Moist slopes and coves with relatively deep, fertile soils. Often these sites have a northern or eastern exposure and are partially shielded from wind and sun. Includes moist mountain tops and saddles.

Name: Narrow floodplains/Bottomlands
Description: Floodplains and bottomlands less than 1/4 mile in width along rivers and streams. These sites are normally well drained but are subjected to occasional flooding during periods of heavy or extended precipitation. Includes associated levees, benches, and terraces within a 1/4 mile limit. Excludes swamps, sloughs, and bogs.

Name: Broad Floodplains/Bottomlands
Description: Floodplains and bottomlands 1/4-mile or wider along rivers and streams. These sites are normally well drained but are subjected to occasional flooding during periods of heavy or extended precipitation. Includes associated levees, benches, and terraces. Excludes swamps, sloughs, and bogs with year-round water problems.

Name: Other Mesic
Description: All moderately moist physiographic sites not described above.

Name: Hydric sites
Description: normally abundant or overabundant moisture all year

Name: Swamps/Bogs
Description: Low, wet, flat, forested areas usually quite extensive that are flooded for long periods except during periods of extreme drought. Excludes cypress ponds and small drains.

Name: Small Drains
Description: Narrow, stream-like, wet strands of forest land often without a well-defined stream channel. These areas are poorly drained or flooded throughout most of the year and drain the adjacent higher ground.

Name: Bays and wet pocosins
Description: Low, wet, boggy sites characterized by peaty or organic soils. May be somewhat dry during periods of extended drought. Examples include sites in the Carolina bays in the Southeast United States.

Name: Forest or Nonforest over Permafrost
Description: Low-lying, sometimes wet, flat areas, often characterized by a thick moss layered ground surface, sometimes comprised of tussocks that tend to form a waterlogged soils layer as the active layer thaws seasonally. Permafrost may be visible or detected with a soil probe. At later periods in the season when permafrost cannot be detected, waterlogged soils layered on top of deeper permafrost are possible
